Introduction

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide and a leading cause of cancer-related mortality.  Although both men and women can develop breast cancer, it is far more common in women.  Early detection through screening and advancements in treatment have significantly improved survival rates.

Pathogenesis



Breast cancer develops through a multistep process driven by a combination of genetic mutations and environmental and hormonal factors.  Key genetic changes in breast cancer involve mutations in tumor suppressor genes such as BRCA1, BRCA2, TP53, and PTEN, as well as in oncogenes such as HER2 (human epidermal growth factor receptor 2).  These mutations lead to disruptions in cell cycle regulation, apoptosis, and DNA repair, contributing to uncontrolled cellular growth and proliferation.

Epidemiology and risk factors



Breast cancer is the most common cancer affecting women worldwide, with a baseline lifetime risk of 1:8 in women.



Many risk factors contribute to the development of breast cancer.  The most significant risk factors include female sex and advancing age.  Other risk factors include:



  • Family history:  first-degree relatives or multiple relatives with breast cancer
  • Genetic mutations:  significantly increased risk in patients with inherited genetic syndromes (eg, BRCA1/2)
  • Hormonal and reproductive factors:  early menarche, late menopause, and nulliparity due to increased lifetime exposure to estrogen
  • Prior breast disease:  previous breast cancer and some benign breast conditions (eg, atypical hyperplasia) or mammographically dense breast tissue
  • Radiation exposure to the chest:  for example, from treatment for Hodgkin lymphoma
  • Menopausal hormone replacement therapy:  estrogen and progesterone therapy (no increased risk for estrogen-only replacement therapy)
  • Lifestyle factors:  alcohol consumption, obesity (after menopause), and lack of physical activity

Pathology



The breast is composed of lobules and ducts surrounded by adipose and fibrous tissue (

figure 1
).  The vast majority of breast cancers are carcinomas that arise from the epithelial components of breast lobules and ducts.  Breast cancer is primarily classified as noninvasive (in situ) or invasive.



  • Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) (
    image 1
    ) is considered a precursor to invasive cancer.  Malignant epithelial cells are confined to the ducts and do not invade the basement membrane or surrounding breast stroma.
  • Invasive ductal carcinoma (also called infiltrating ductal carcinoma) (
    image 2
    ) is the most common type of invasive breast cancer (70%-80%).  Malignant cells originate from the ductal epithelium and invade surrounding breast tissue.  Invasive cancer cells form nests and induce a fibrotic response, leading to a firm, irregular mass.
  • Invasive lobular carcinoma (also called infiltrating lobular carcinoma (
    image 3
    ) is the second most common type of invasive breast cancer (5%-10%).  Malignant cells arise from the lobules of the breast and invade the surrounding breast tissue in a single-file or individual fashion.  These tumors often present with diffuse growth and may not cause a well-defined mass.
  • Inflammatory breast cancer (
    figure 2
    ) accounts for <5% of invasive breast cancers.  It is an aggressive form of breast cancer that invades dermal lymphatics (causing the characteristic peau d'orange appearance) and blood vessels, leading to early spread of malignant cells.  Therefore, it is often advanced at the initial clinical presentation.  This topic is discussed in detail in a separate dedicated article.
  • Other types of breast cancer include medullary, mucinous, and tubular carcinomas, each with their own histology.  However, these are rare and are not the focus of this article.


Breast cancer is also classified based on molecular markers:



  • Estrogen/progesterone (ER/PR)-positive:  Tumors that express estrogen and/or progesterone receptors are often more responsive to hormone therapy.
  • HER2-positive:  HER2 is a transmembrane receptor protein involved in cell signaling pathways that stimulate cellular proliferation.  Tumor overexpression of HER2 is associated with aggressive behavior but is treatable with targeted therapies like trastuzumab.
  • Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC):  TNBC lacks estrogen, progesterone, and HER2 overexpression and is typically more aggressive with fewer treatment options.

Clinical presentation



The clinical presentation of breast cancer varies, but the vast majority of patients are asymptomatic and are diagnosed after abnormalities (eg, soft tissue density, microcalcifications) are found on screening mammograms.



When symptoms are present, they include:



  • Breast or axillary mass (common) or pain (rare)
  • Nipple or skin changes
  • Nipple discharge
  • Symptoms of advanced disease, which are based on location of distant metastases and may include bone pain, shortness of breath, jaundice, or neurologic symptoms

Physical examination



Physical examination findings suspicious for breast cancer include:



  • Breast mass that is typically painless, immobile (fixed to surrounding tissue), and firm with irregular borders.
  • Skin changes:  include dimpling, redness, or thickening of the breast skin (inflammatory breast cancer characteristically causes rapid onset erythema and edema of the skin of the breast).
  • Nipple changes:  include retraction, inversion, or discharge (particularly, bloody discharge).
  • Painless lymphadenopathy:  occurs when the lymphatics of the breast are drained by the axillary, supraclavicular, and internal mammary nodes.  Palpation of these regions may show lymphadenopathy if cancer has spread to the lymph nodes.

Diagnosis



The diagnosis of breast cancer requires histologic evaluation of biopsy or surgical specimens, which is prompted following an imaging evaluation.



The imaging evaluation arises from either screening (ie, routine asymptomatic patients) or diagnostic (ie, symptomatic patients) studies.

Imaging studies



  • Mammography or x-ray of the breast:  can be performed for routine screening or in evaluation of a patient with a breast mass.  Suspicious features include microcalcifications (
    image 4
    ), mass lesions with spiculated or irregular borders (
    image 5
    ), architectural distortion, and asymmetry.
  • Ultrasonography:  is used with mammography to further characterize breast masses.  It is also often the primary imaging modality to evaluate breast masses in younger women (age <30) with dense breast tissue.
  • MRI:  is used for screening in high-risk patients (eg, carriers of BRCA mutation) or for surgical planning in patients with breast cancer.


Following an imaging study, the Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BI-RADS) is used to determine a standardized score to stratify the risk for malignancy and guide the need for biopsy or surgical resection.  The scoring system is as follows:



  • 0:  needs additional evaluation
  • 1:  normal findings
  • 2:  benign lesion
  • 3:  probably benign lesion (malignancy risk <2%)
  • 4:  suspicious for malignancy (broad category with malignancy risk between 2%-95%)
  • 5:  high risk for malignancy (malignancy risk 95%-100%)
  • 6:  biopsy-proven malignancy


All scores of 0, 4, or 5 require additional intervention with further imaging studies, close imaging follow-up, or biopsy.

Biopsy



Biopsy of suspicious lesions can be performed via:



  • Core needle biopsy (
    figure 3
    ):  is the preferred method of biopsy because it extracts a "core" sample of breast tissue.  It is usually performed under imaging guidance to directly target the abnormal area for sampling.
  • Fine-needle aspiration (FNA):  is inferior to core needle biopsy for evaluation of breast masses because it does not maintain tissue architecture (ie, cannot distinguish between invasive and in situ carcinoma) and has a higher false-negative rate.  It is most often used for cyst aspiration (
    figure 4
    ) and to evaluate for lymph node metastases in patients with cancer.
  • Excisional biopsy:  involves complete removal of a breast mass for diagnosis.  It is usually performed when core needle biopsy is inconclusive or inconsistent with imaging findings or if a core needle biopsy is not technically feasible.


Pathological evaluation gives the definitive diagnosis and determines tumor histology, grade, and molecular markers (ER, PR, HER2), which guides treatment.

Staging



Breast cancer can be staged clinically or pathologically through surgery.  Although surgical staging is more accurate, clinical staging is useful in making initial treatment recommendations, and the staging can be updated following a review of the pathology.  A general overview of breast cancer staging is as follows:



  • Tis:  carcinoma in situ
  • T1-4:  determined by the size of the tumor
  • T4:  extension of tumor into chest wall/skin or distant metastases

Management



Breast cancer treatment is based on the stage of the tumor in addition to grade and molecular makeup (ie, hormone receptor status).  Components of treatment include surgery, systemic therapy, and radiation.

Surgical therapy



Surgical management consists of breast-conserving treatment or mastectomy.  The procedure depends on tumor size, tumor grade, concern for metastases, and patient preference.



  • Breast-conserving treatment (lumpectomy) removes the tumor to the margins of normal tissue.
  • Mastectomy is complete removal of the breast tissue.


Axillary lymph node assessment is required for metastasis evaluation.  This can be performed via:



  • Sentinel lymph node biopsy:  often performed in patients with low suspicion for involvement of lymph nodes.  This procedure removes fewer lymph nodes (compared to full dissection) by using a radioactive substance to identify the initial lymph nodes draining the malignant tissue for removal and evaluation.
  • Axillary lymph node dissection:  performed in patients with known or suspected spread of malignant cells to the lymph nodes.  This procedure completely excises the axillary lymph nodes.  Therefore, it is associated with increased adverse effects (eg, chronic lymphedema).

Systemic therapy



Systemic therapy is used before (neoadjuvant) or after (adjuvant) surgical intervention and includes hormone therapy, targeted therapy, and chemotherapy.



Hormone therapy is used in ER/PR-positive cancers to block the stimulatory effect of estrogen on breast tissue and reduce tumor proliferation.  Most commonly, this is done with selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs) or aromatase inhibitors.  The choice of agent is dependent upon menopausal status:



  • Postmenopausal women:  Aromatase inhibitors (eg, letrozole, anastrozole, exemestane) block the conversion of androgens to estrogens by peripheral fat tissue and are the first-line hormone therapy in postmenopausal patients.
  • Premenopausal women:  Tamoxifen is a SERM that acts as a competitive antagonist of the estrogen receptor in breast tissue and is first-line therapy for most premenopausal patients with estrogen/progesterone-positive cancers.  Aromatase inhibitors are ineffective in premenopausal patients due to ongoing estrogen production by the ovaries.  Some high-risk premenopausal patients are treated with combined aromatase inhibitors and ovarian function suppression (eg, GnRH agonist or oophorectomy).


Endocrine therapy is typically used for a minimum of 5 years with an option to extend the therapy in high-risk patients (eg, those with large primary tumors or positive lymph nodes).



Targeted therapy is used in patients with HER2-positive cancers.  It involves monoclonal antibodies (eg, trastuzumab) that specifically target HER2 receptors, which block cell signaling pathways within tumor proliferation.



Chemotherapy is most often used in patients with TNBC, high-risk features (eg, large tumors, lymph node involvement), or metastasis.  Common regimens include doxorubicin, cyclophosphamide, and paclitaxel.

Radiation



Radiation can be administered to the whole breast or as brachytherapy.  It is often used following surgery to prevent local recurrences of breast cancer by eradicating any remaining tumor deposits.



In general, DCIS or early-stage breast cancer is treated with surgery followed by adjuvant therapy, which is determined by the molecular makeup of the primary tumor.  In cases of locally advanced tumors, neoadjuvant therapy may be necessary prior to surgery.  For metastatic breast cancer, systemic therapy is the primary treatment.

Prognosis



Prognosis is highly dependent on the stage (determined by tumor size, nodal involvement, and presence or absence of metastatic disease) and molecular characteristics of the tumor:



  • Early-stage breast cancer (Stage I-II):  The 5-year survival rate is over 90%.  If cancer cells have not spread beyond the breast, survival rate is 99%.
  • Locally advanced breast cancer (Stage III):  The 5-year survival rate is over 70%.
  • Metastatic breast cancer (Stage IV):  This is unlikely to be cured.  The median survival is nearly 3 years for estrogen-negative cancers and nearly 5 years for estrogen-positive cancers.


Factors associated with a poorer prognosis include the following:



  • Certain patient characteristics, such as age <35 or >65 and cigarette smoking, are associated with a worse prognosis.
  • Larger tumor size, involvement of lymph nodes, and presence of metastatic disease raise the stage of the cancer and are associated with a worse prognosis.
  • Molecular characteristics of cancers, such as hormone receptor (estrogen/progesterone)â€“negative cancers and TNBC, tend to be associated with a worse prognosis.  In the past, cancers with HER2 overexpression have had a poor prognosis, but targeted treatments have led to improved survival.
  • Inflammatory breast cancer is associated with a poorer prognosis.

Complications



Breast cancer survivors are at risk for long-term complications due to treatments and therapies.  Patients treated with mastectomies are at increased risk for:



  • Chest wall complications, such as seromas, fat necrosis, and recurrent cellulitis
  • Chronic pain and reduced arm mobility (due to stiffness from the pectoralis major), which may be compounded by radiation therapy in the short and long term
  • Possible nerve injury, such as injury causing permanent paresthesia in the chest wall


Risks associated with axillary lymph node dissections include chronic lymphedema, which places patients at risk for angiosarcoma, a rare and aggressive malignancy with a poor prognosis.  This is likely due to increased lymphatic proliferation, which increases the likelihood of malignant cells, and a decreased number of lymph nodes, which decreases the ability to remove the malignant cells.

Recurrence



The recurrence rates of breast cancer are highly influenced by the initial molecular and pathological subtype of the index cancer as well as initial surgical management (breast-conserving therapy vs mastectomy).  For most patients, the highest risk for recurrence occurs within the first few years following treatment.  Those with HER2 receptor positivity are associated with early recurrence events (most within 5 years of diagnosis).  Patients with late recurrences generally have a more favorable prognosis than those with immediate or early recurrences.



For women treated with breast-conserving therapy, annual mammography is used for detecting early local recurrences and screening the contralateral breast.  For patients treated with mastectomy, physical examinations are performed to detect recurrences.

Screening



Routine mammography is recommended every 1-2 years for women beginning at age 40-50 depending on patient risk factors and preferences.  Women at high risk (eg, BRCA mutations, strong family history) should begin screening at an earlier age and may be offered screening breast MRI in addition to mammography.  Screening beyond age 75 is appropriate for some patients based on life expectancy and overall health status.



A more detailed discussion of screening and management in patients with BRCA mutations can be found in a separate dedicated article.

Prevention



The goal of most breast cancer prevention strategies is early detection through screening.  Other strategies to reduce the risk for breast cancer development include:



  • Lifestyle modifications with regular physical activity, healthy weight maintenance, and limited alcohol intake
  • Breastfeeding during childbearing years
  • Identification of high-risk patients with genetic counseling and testing.  Women with hereditary cancer syndromes (eg, BRCA1/2) should be counseled on risk reduction surgeries (eg, prophylactic mastectomy, oophorectomy) or chemoprevention with agents like tamoxifen or raloxifene.

Special considerations:  breast cancer in men



Breast cancer in men is rare, representing 0.5%-1% of all breast cancers diagnosed each year.  Risk factors are similar in men and women, with the most significant being family history, genetic history, and increasing age.  Men with BRCA2 mutations have the highest risk for developing breast cancer.  Breast cancer is typically diagnosed at a more advanced stage in men than in women, mainly because of the lack of awareness of breast cancer in men.  The most common presentation is a firm, painless subareolar mass.  Treatment for men is dependent upon stage and molecular composition and involves the same components as in women: surgery, radiation, and systemic therapy.

Summary



Breast cancer is a complex disease with multiple subtypes that require tailored management.  Early detection through screening and advances in targeted therapies have improved outcomes, but prognosis varies widely based on stage at diagnosis and molecular characteristics.  Prevention and early detection, especially for high-risk individuals, are crucial in reducing breast cancer incidence and mortality.
